SEARCH

Package org.loudouncodes.combinatorics

package org.loudouncodes.combinatorics
A tiny, classroom-friendly library for generating common combinatorial objects you can iterate with Java's enhanced for-loop. The goal is practical puzzle power: small, predictable tools that make it easy to brute-force or explore toy problems (card games like Set, recreational math, small search spaces), without dragging in a full discrete math course.

What lives in this package?

  • Combinations — all size-k subsets of {0..n-1} in lexicographic order. Unordered, no repetition. Iterable of int[].
  • Permutations — all ordered k-tuples from {0..n-1} without repetition (so nPk total). Iterable of int[].
  • Derangements — permutations of 0..n-1 with no fixed points (for every i, p[i] != i). Iterable of int[].
  • CombinationsWithRepetition — size-k multisets from {0..n-1} (repeats allowed), emitted as non-decreasing arrays. Iterable of int[].
  • CartesianProduct — all tuples from multiple domains (think nested loops flattened). Pass sizes like (2,3,4) and get every index triple where 0 <= a < 2, 0 <= b < 3, 0 <= c < 4. Iterable of int[].
  • IndexingAdapter<E> — bridges from indices to elements. Wrap any Iterable<int[]> together with a List<E> and iterate List<E> tuples (each result is an unmodifiable list).

Each generator returns defensive copies on next(), so students can safely mutate what they get without breaking the iterator.

Why indices?

Every generator in this package works over the integer domain {0..n-1}. This keeps the core algorithms tiny and fast. When you want real objects (cards, strings, students), use IndexingAdapter to map index tuples to element tuples.

Quick examples

1) Choose teams: combinations (unordered, no repeats)


 import java.util.*;
 import org.loudouncodes.combinatorics.*;

 List<String> names = List.of("Ada", "Grace", "Edsger", "Barbara");
 for (List<String> pair :
       new IndexingAdapter<>(new Combinations(2, names.size()), names)) {
     System.out.println(pair);
 }
 // [Ada, Grace], [Ada, Edsger], [Ada, Barbara], [Grace, Edsger], [Grace, Barbara], [Edsger, Barbara]

2) Order tasks: permutations (ordered, no repeats)


 List<String> tasks = List.of("A", "B", "C");
 for (List<String> seq :
       new IndexingAdapter<>(new Permutations(2, tasks.size()), tasks)) {
     System.out.println(seq);
 }
 // [A, B], [A, C], [B, A], [B, C], [C, A], [C, B]

3) Secret-Santa style: derangements (no fixed points)


 List<String> people = List.of("Ann", "Ben", "Cam", "Dee");
 for (int[] p : new Derangements(people.size())) {
     boolean ok = true;
     for (int i = 0; i < p.length; i++) if (p[i] == i) ok = false;
     if (ok) {
         for (int i = 0; i < p.length; i++) {
             System.out.printf("%s → %s  ", people.get(i), people.get(p[i]));
         }
         System.out.println();
     }
 }

4) Build the Set deck: Cartesian product + mapping

The game Set has 4 attributes with 3 values each. The deck is the 4-way product 3^4 = 81: 


 // Attribute domains (encoded 0..2 each): number, color, shape, fill
 String[][] attrs = {
   {"1","2","3"},      // number
   {"red","green","purple"}, // color
   {"oval","squiggle","diamond"}, // shape
   {"solid","striped","open"}     // fill
 };

 // Build a human-readable card list by mapping index tuples to strings
 for (int[] t : new CartesianProduct(3,3,3,3)) {
   String card = attrs[0][t[0]] + " " + attrs[1][t[1]] + " " + attrs[2][t[2]] + " " + attrs[3][t[3]];
   System.out.println(card);
 }
 // 81 lines like: "1 red oval solid", "1 red oval striped", ...

5) Triples from a 12-card layout: combinations again


 // Suppose 'layout' is a List<Card> of size 12
 // Iterate all 3-card subsets; plug in your "isSet" predicate inside the loop.
 for (int[] c : new Combinations(3, 12)) {
   // c[0], c[1], c[2] are indices into layout
   // if (isSet(layout.get(c[0]), layout.get(c[1]), layout.get(c[2]))) { ... }
 }

Performance notes

  • Each generator is lazy: nothing is precomputed; the next tuple is constructed on demand.
  • size() methods return counts in long; they overflow for large inputs by design (this is a classroom library; keep problem sizes modest).
  • Returned arrays (and lists from IndexingAdapter) are new objects per call so students can mutate them without affecting iteration.

What we intentionally did not include (yet)

General power sets, set partitions, and integer partitions blow up very quickly and are more about discrete math than puzzle solving. If you ever need them, they can be added later as separate iterables with the same style.

Tip for teachers

A fun exercise is to have students replace nested loops with a single enhanced for over one of these generators. It makes search code shorter and emphasizes the shape of the search space (subsets vs. ordered tuples vs. products).

Since:
0.1.0
  • Classes
    Class
    Description
    CartesianProduct
    Generates the Cartesian product of multiple domains, each defined by its size, and exposes the tuples via Java's enhanced for loop by implementing Iterable<int[]>.
    Combinations
    Generates all k-combinations (unordered, without repetition) from the integer domain {0, 1, ..., n-1} in lexicographic order and exposes them via Java's enhanced for loop by implementing Iterable<int[]>.
    CombinationsWithRepetition
    Generates all k-combinations with repetition (a.k.a.
    Derangements
    Generates all derangements of {0,1,...,n-1} and exposes them via Java's enhanced for loop by implementing Iterable<int[]>.
    IndexingAdapter<E>
    Adapts an Iterable<int[]> of index tuples to an Iterable<List<E>> of element tuples, using a provided List<E> as the backing source.
    Permutations
    Generates ordered k-permutations (k-tuples without repetition) drawn from the integer domain {0, 1, ..., n-1} and exposes them via Java's enhanced for loop by implementing Iterable<int[]>.
